Award.AwardTitle: INSPIRE: Asynchronous communication, self-organization, and differentiation in human and insect networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This INSPIRE award is partially funded by the Perception, Action, and Cognition Program in the Division of Behavioral and Cognitive Sciences in the Directorate for Social, Behavioral and Economic Sciences, the Animal Behavior Program in the Division of Integrative Organismal Systems in the Directorate for Biology, and the Dynamical Systems Program in the Division of Civil, Mechanical & Manufacturing Innovation in the Directorate for Engineering.

The project explores the question of how the activities of individuals become integrated into a smoothly functioning society: What are the dominant mechanisms? How resilient are they? How do they depend on the properties of individual society members? To this end, investigators from engineering, biology, psychology and linguistics will work together to study bee colonies and groups of humans to understand how organization and coordination emerges from these multi-agent systems and the factors that influence their robustness and resilience to perturbations. The project relies on quantitative observations of the dynamic emergence of patterns of interaction and coordination using an unprecedented, 24/7 monitoring system of a beehive as well as in groups of humans under controlled conditions designed to distinguish between failed and successful coordination. The investigators will pursue a combined theoretical, experimental, and computational framework for characterizing the resultant parallel and asynchronous communication systems. The work depends crucially on the interdisciplinary framework and the direct involvement of content expertise from the disciplines represented by the investigators. For example, the human transportation network is designed to resemble the coordinated delivery of nectar through a beehive, but with options for varying the number of different materials transported, the size of arena, the flow rates of the materials, and so on.

The investigators are exploring whether a comprehensive computational framework can be discovered to understand, predict and prevent the collapse of very different types of communities (bees and human networks). The research results are expected to provide insight into how to manipulate the behavior of a complex system, for example to address societal challenges associated with the collapse of pollinating bee colonies or the destructive behavior that is often associated with phases of social transition in groups of humans.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In this work we combined experimental data from communities of social insects, as well as small groups of humans, with mathematical analysis and computer algorithms. We learned about the relationship between the nature of interactions within such communities and the way they self-organize to achieve desirable collective function. We made new knowledge available to the general public and created access to new research data and software tools. We provided extensive interdisciplinary training to a large number of undergraduates, graduate students, and postdoctoral scholars from engineering, computer science, psychology, physics, and biology. We disseminated the project outcomes through scholarly channels, conference presentations, and invited seminars across multiple distinct disciplines. 

We studied feeding activities in bee colonies as an example of unconstrained social interaction. We discovered patterns of timing and sequencing of such interactions that were associated with increased potential for information transmission compared to randomized simulation models. Interestingly, similar patterns had previously been found in human communication networks, but there associated with decreased potential for information transfer. We developed sophisticated computer-aided tools for automatic monitoring of bee behavior at a rate of one image per second for 8-11 days and produced large data sets for five experimental colonies that were made freely available to the public. We further engaged the public through an NSF Science Nation video and as part of direct annual outreach to beekeepers. The unexpected observation of the properties of the honeybee social network and the generation of new experimental tools and publicly-available datasets were significant outcomes of this project. 

In parallel, we studied the dynamics of small groups of humans playing computer games as an example of constrained social interaction. In analogy to the social insect communities, we designed games in which the information available to each individual participant was sourced from a particular subset of other participants. A successful outcome of such a game required participants to uncover preferences or choices made by other participants through the actions they took rather than through direct communication. In some game designs, repeat success required participants to self-organize into different roles. We discovered conditions that resulted in groups getting temporarily stuck in arrangements of contradictory roles or preferences rather than complementary roles and preferences. Such arrangements were difficult to escape, since this required being willing to take on short-term losses in favor of long-term gains. We built a computer model that captured the patterns observed in the human data surprisingly well, shedding light on the general principles underlying success as well as failure to coordinate. We implemented a cloud-based version of the coordination games to enable access to a significantly larger population than typical of academic research. The insights into human group coordination and the deployment of experimental tools on a third-party cloud-based platform were significant outcomes of this project.

In a complementary strand, we investigated statistical tools and mathematical models for characterizing and explaining time-dependent behavior in social interaction networks. We drew from engineering knowledge about systems of coupled mechanical oscillators in order to study a general principle of self-organization: can a complex system redesign itself in real time in order to achieve a globally optimal collective behavior using only local interactions between its components? We discovered that intuitive rules for redesign could result in suboptimal global behaviors. We even found predictable conditions in which local interactions would lead to a race to the bottom. Surprisingly, even as the components of the system appeared to be making progress toward the desired outcome, conflicting information across the system conspired against success, propelling the system toward overall dysfunction and collapse. We studied other forms of organization in order to better characterize properties of real-world empirical datasets, e.g., those describing proximity among coworkers in a workspace or ants interacting in a colony. Motivated by our analysis of information transmission in the honeybee dataset, we simulated disease spreading and opinion formation piggybacking on empirical data of time-varying interactions. We discovered that such simulations could give useful information about the original data set provided that comparison could be made with a suitably randomized data set, lacking some essential features of the original data. We developed several new protocols for randomization and showed how they could be used. The observation that locally optimal response in a complex system could result in global dysfunction, as well as the invention of new statistical tools for network analysis were significant outcomes of this project.
